Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story:
The clock on my telemarketing dashboard blinked 2:00 PM, signaling the end of my lunch break. I was supposed to return to my headset, ready to dial the next number, my every minute tracked by the compliance system. Any unscheduled pause, even for a moment, would be flagged, and I’d have to explain myself to my supervisor. But today, the convent was unusually quiet. The other sisters were out, and I had planned this rare afternoon for spiritual reading and silent reflection—a time I cherished, a time I felt closest to my calling as a nun.

Yet, as I sat with my Bible open, the headset on my desk seemed to glare at me, a reminder of the world’s demands. My heart ached for the peace of prayer, but my mind buzzed with anxiety about the system’s watchful eye. I could not ignore the pressure to perform at work, nor could I dismiss the longing for spiritual nourishment. The two worlds pulled at me, each insistent, each righteous in its own way. I closed my eyes, torn, the silence of the convent now filled with the noise of my inner struggle.
